abbreviate.description: Abbreviate strings to at least minlength characters,such that they remain unique (if they were),unless strict = TRUE.

abs.description: abs(x) computes the absolute value of x, sqrt(x) computes the(principal) square root of x, √{x}.

cos.description: These functions give the obvious trigonometric functions.  Theyrespectively compute the cosine, sine, tangent, arc-cosine, arc-sine,arc-tangent, and the two-argument arc-tangent.

cosh.description: These functions give the obvious hyperbolic functions.  Theyrespectively compute the hyperbolic cosine, sine, tangent, and theirinverses, arc-cosine, arc-sine, arc-tangent (or ‘area cosine’,etc).

addTaskCallback.description: addTaskCallback registers an R functionthat is to be called each time a top-level taskis completed.

displayText: agrep(pattern, x, max.distance = 0.1, costs = NULL,ignore.case = FALSE, value = FALSE, fixed = TRUE,useBytes = FALSE)
agrepl(pattern, x, max.distance = 0.1, costs = NULL, ignore.case = FALSE, fixed = TRUE, useBytes = FALSE)
agrep.description: Searches for approximate matches to pattern (the first argument)within each element of the string x (the second argument) usingthe generalized Levenshtein edit distance (the minimal possiblyweighted number of insertions, deletions and substitutions needed totransform one string into another).

list.description: Functions to construct, coerce and check for both kinds of R lists.

all.description: Given a set of logical vectors, are all of the values true?

all.equal.description: all.equal(x, y) is a utility to compare R objects xand y testing ‘near equality’.  If they are different,comparison is still made to some extent, and a report of thedifferences is returned.    Do not use all.equal directly inif expressions—either use isTRUE(all.equal(....)) oridentical if appropriate.

all.vars(expr, functions = FALSE, max.names = -1L, unique = TRUE)

There are also constants NA_integer_,NA_real_, NA_complex_ and NA_character_ of theother atomic vector types which support missing values: all of theseare reserved words in the R language.

TRUE\nFALSE\nT; F\n\nlogical.description: Create or test for objects of type "logical", and the basiclogical constants.

NULL\nas.null.description: NULL represents the null object in R: it is a reservedword.  NULL is often returned by expressions and functionswhose value is undefined.

numeric.description: Creates or coerces objects of type "numeric".is.numeric is a more general test of an object beinginterpretable as numbers.

qr.description: qr computes the QR decomposition of a matrix.

vector.description: vector produces a vector of the given length and mode.

attach.description: The database is attached to the R search path.  This means that thedatabase is searched by R when evaluating a variable, so objects inthe database can be accessed by simply giving their names.

displayText: loadNamespace(package, lib.loc = NULL,keep.source = getOption("keep.source.pkgs"),partial = FALSE, versionCheck = NULL)
attachNamespace.description: Functions to load and unload name spaces.

attr.description: Get or set specific attributes of an object.

attributes.description: These functions access an object's attributes.The first form below returns the object's attribute list.The replacement forms uses the list on the right-handside of the assignment as the object's attributes (if appropriate).

autoload.description: autoload creates a promise-to-evaluate autoloader andstores it with name name in .AutoloadEnv environment.When R attempts to evaluate name, autoloader is run,the package is loaded and name is re-evaluated in the newpackage's environment.  The result is that R behaves as iffile was loaded but it does not occupy memory.

forwardsolve(l, x, k = ncol(l), upper.tri = FALSE, transpose = FALSE)
backsolve.description: Solves a triangular system of linear equations.

environment.description: Get, set, test for and create environments.

basename.description: basename removes all of the path up to and including the lastpath separator (if any).

besselI.description: Bessel Functions of integer and fractional order, of firstand second kind, J(nu) and Y(nu), andModified Bessel functions (of first and third kind),I(nu) and K(nu).

beta.description: Special mathematical functions related to the beta and gammafunctions.

lockEnvironment.description: These functions represent an interface for adjustmentsto environments and bindings within environments.  They allow forlocking environments as well as individual bindings, and for linkinga variable to a function.

gettext.description: If Native Language Support was enabled in this build of R, attempt totranslate character vectors or set where the translations are to be found.

bitwNot.description: Logical operations on integer vectors with elements viewed as sets of bits.

body.description: Get or set the body of a function.

bquote.description: An analogue of the LISP backquote macro.  bquote quotes itsargument except that terms wrapped in .() are evaluated in thespecified where environment.

displayText: for(var in seq) exprwhile(cond) exprrepeat exprbreaknext)
if.description: These are the basic control-flow constructs of the R language.  Theyfunction in much the same way as control statements in any Algol-likelanguage.  They are all reserved words.

browser.displayText: browser(text = "", condition = NULL, expr = TRUE, skipCalls = 0L)
browser.description: Interrupt the execution of an expression and allow the inspection ofthe environment where browser was called from.

browserText.description: A call to browser can provide context by supplying either a textargument or a condition argument.  These functions can be used toretrieve either of these arguments.

builtins.description: Return the names of all the built-in objects.  These are fetcheddirectly from the symbol table of the R interpreter.

by.description: Function by is an object-oriented wrapper fortapply applied to data frames.

displayText: file(description = "", open = "", blocking = TRUE, encoding = getOption("encoding"), raw = FALSE)
url(description, open = "", blocking = TRUE,encoding = getOption("encoding"), method)
fifo(description, open = "", blocking = FALSE, encoding = getOption("encoding"))
socketConnection(host = "localhost", port, server = FALSE, blocking = FALSE, open = "a+", encoding = getOption("encoding"), timeout = getOption("timeout"))
file.description: Functions to create, open and close connections, i.e.,“generalized files”, such as possibly compressed files, URLs,pipes, etc.

c.description: This is a generic function which combines its arguments.

warnings.description: warnings and its print method print thevariable last.warning in a pleasing form.

callCC.description: A downward-only version of Scheme's call with current continuation.

capabilities.description: Report on the optional features which have been compiled into thisbuild of R.

chartr.description: Translate characters in character vectors, in particular from upper tolower case or vice versa.

cat.displayText: cat(... , file = "", sep = " ", fill = FALSE, labels = NULL,append = FALSE)
cat.description: Outputs the objects, concatenating the representations.  catperforms much less conversion than print.

cbind.description: Take a sequence of vector, matrix or data-frame arguments and combineby columns or rows, respectively.  These are genericfunctions with methods for other R classes.

ceiling.description: ceiling takes a single numeric argument x and returns anumeric vector containing the smallest integers not less than thecorresponding elements of x.

char.expand.description: Seeks a unique match of its first argument among theelements of its second.  If successful, it returns this element;otherwise, it performs an action specified by the third argument.

charmatch.description: charmatch seeks matches for the elements of its first argumentamong those of its second.

charToRaw.description: Conversion and manipulation of  objects of type "raw".

chkDots.description: Warn about extraneous arguments in the ... of its caller.  Autility to be used e.g., in S3 methods which need a formal ...argument but do not make any use of it.  This helps catching usererrors in calling the function in question (which is the caller ofchkDots().

chol.description: Compute the Choleski factorization of a real symmetricpositive-definite square matrix.

chol2inv.description: Invert a symmetric, positive definite square matrix from its Choleskidecomposition.  Equivalently, compute (X'X)^(-1)from the (R part) of the QR decomposition of X.

class.description: R possesses a simple generic function mechanism which can be used foran object-oriented style of programming.  Method dispatch takes placebased on the class of the first argument to the generic function.

displayText: pushBack(data, connection, newLine = TRUE, encoding = c("", "bytes", "UTF-8")
pushBack.description: Functions to push back text lines onto a connection, and to enquirehow many lines are currently pushed back.

function.description: These functions provide the base mechanisms for definingnew functions in the R language.

utf8ToInt.description: Conversion of UTF-8 encoded character vectors to and from integer vectors.

col.description: Returns a matrix of integers indicating their column number in amatrix-like object, or a factor of column labels.

colSums.description: Form row and column sums and means for numeric arrays.

rownames.description: Retrieve or set the row or column names of a matrix-like object.

commandArgs.description: Provides access to a copy of the command line arguments supplied whenthis R session was invoked.

comment.description: These functions set and query a commentattribute for any R objects.  This is typically useful fordata.frames or model fits.

Math.description: Group generic methods can be defined for four pre-specified groups offunctions, Math, Ops, Summary and Complex.(There are no objects of these names in base R, but there are in themethods package.)

conflicts.description: conflicts reports on objects that exist with the same name intwo or more places on the search path, usually becausean object in the user's workspace or a package is masking a systemobject of the same name.  This helps discover unintentional masking.

contributors.description: The R Who-is-who, describing who made significant contributions tothe development of R.

crossprod.description: Given matrices x and y as arguments, return a matrixcross-product.  This is formally equivalent to (but usually slightlyfaster than) the call t(x) %*% y (crossprod) orx %*% t(y) (tcrossprod).

Cstack_info.description: Report information on the C stack size and usage (if available).

cumsum.description: Returns a vector whose elements are the cumulative sums, products,minima or maxima of the elements of the argument.

curlGetHeaders.description: Retrieve the headers for a URL for a supported protocol such ashttp://, ftp://, https:// and ftps://.An optional function not supported on all platforms.

displayText: cut(x, breaks, labels = NULL,include.lowest = FALSE, right = TRUE, dig.lab = 3,ordered_result = FALSE, ...)
cut.description: cut divides the range of x into intervalsand codes the values in x according to whichinterval they fall.  The leftmost interval corresponds to level one,the next leftmost to level two and so on.

displayText: cut(x, breaks, labels = NULL, start.on.monday = TRUE,right = FALSE, ...)
cut(x, breaks, labels = NULL, start.on.monday = TRUE,right = FALSE, ...)
cut.1.description: Method for cut applied to date-time objects.

data.class.description: Determine the class of an arbitrary R object.

displayText: data.frame(..., row.names = NULL, check.rows = FALSE, check.names = TRUE, stringsAsFactors = default.stringsAsFactors())
data.frame.description: This function creates data frames, tightly coupledcollections of variables which share many of the properties ofmatrices and of lists, used as the fundamental data structure by mostof R's modeling software.

data.matrix.description: Return the matrix obtained by converting all the variables in a dataframe to numeric mode and then binding them together as the columns ofa matrix.  Factors and ordered factors are replaced by their internalcodes.

date.description: Returns a character string of the current system date and time.

debug.description: Set, unset or query the debugging flag on a function.The text and condition arguments are the same as thosethat can be supplied via a call to browser. They can be retrievedby the user once the browser has been entered, and provide a mechanism toallow users to identify which breakpoint has been activated.

.Defunct.description: When a function is removed from R it should be replaced by a functionwhich calls .Defunct.

delayedAssign.description: delayedAssign creates a promise to evaluate the givenexpression if its value is requested.  This provides direct accessto the lazy evaluation mechanism used by R for the evaluationof (interpreted) functions.

deparse.description: Turn unevaluated expressions into character strings.

.Deprecated.description: When an object is about to be removed from R it is first deprecated andshould include a call to .Deprecated.

det.description: det calculates the determinant of a matrix.  determinantis a generic function that returns separately the modulus of the determinant,optionally on the logarithm scale, and the sign of the determinant.

detach.displayText: detach(name, pos = 2L, unload = FALSE, character.only = FALSE, force = FALSE)
detach.description: Detach a database, i.e., remove it from the search()path of available R objects.  Usually this is either adata.frame which has been attached or apackage which was attached by library.

dput.description: Writes an ASCII text representation of an R object to a fileor connection, or uses one to recreate the object.

diag.description: Extract or replace the diagonal of a matrix,or construct a diagonal matrix.

diff.description: Returns suitably lagged and iterated differences.

dim.description: Retrieve or set the dimension of an object.

displayText: provideDimnames(x, sep = "", base = list(LETTERS), unique = TRUE)

dump.description: This function takes a vector of names of R objects and producestext representations of the objects on a file or connection.A dump file can usually be sourced into anotherR session.

dyn.load.description: Load or unload DLLs (also known as shared objects), and test whether aC function or Fortran subroutine is available.

eapply.description: eapply applies FUN to the named values from anenvironment and returns the results as a list.  The usercan request that all named objects are used (normally names that beginwith a dot are not).  The output is not sorted and no enclosingenvironments are searched.

get0(x, envir = pos.to.env(-1L), mode = "any", inherits = TRUE, ifnotfound = NULL)

expand.grid.description: Create a data frame from all combinations of the supplied vectors orfactors.  See the description of the return value for precise details ofthe way this is done.

file.show.description: Display one or more (plain) text files, in a platformspecific way, typically via a ‘pager’.

displayText: Reduce(f, x, init, right = FALSE, accumulate = FALSE)
Find(f, x, right = FALSE, nomatch = NULL)
Position(f, x, right = FALSE, nomatch = NA_integer_)
Reduce.description: Reduce uses a binary function to successively combine theelements of a given vector and a possibly given initial value.Filter extracts the elements of a vector for which a predicate(logical) function gives true.  Find and Position givethe first or last such element and its position in the vector,respectively.  Map applies a function to the correspondingelements of given vectors.  Negate creates the negation of agiven function.

reg.finalizer.description: Registers an R function to be called upon garbage collection ofobject or (optionally) at the end of an R session.

displayText: find.package(package, lib.loc = NULL, quiet = FALSE, verbose = getOption("verbose"))
find.package.description: Find the paths to one or more packages.

findInterval.displayText: findInterval(x, vec, rightmost.closed = FALSE, all.inside = FALSE)
findInterval.description: Given a vector of non-decreasing breakpoints in vec, find theinterval containing each element of x; i.e., ifi <- findInterval(x,v), for each index j in xv[i[j]] ≤ x[j] < v[i[j] + 1]where v[0] := - Inf,v[N+1] := + Inf, and N <- length(v).At the two boundaries, the returned index may differ by 1, dependingon the optional arguments rightmost.closed and all.inside.

is.finite.description: is.finite and is.infinite return a vector of the samelength as x, indicating which elements are finite (not infiniteand not missing) or infinite.

forceAndCall.description: Call a function with a specified number of leading arguments forcedbefore the call if the function is a closure.

.Fortran(.NAME, ..., NAOK = FALSE, DUP = TRUE, PACKAGE, ENCODING)
.C.description: Functions to make calls to compiled code that has been loaded into R.

formals.description: Get or set the formal arguments of a function.

displayText: format(x, trim = FALSE, digits = NULL, nsmall = 0L, justify = c("left", "right", "centre", "none"), width = NULL, na.encode = TRUE, scientific = NA, big.mark = "", big.interval = 3L, small.mark = "", small.interval = 5L, decimal.mark = getOption("OutDec"), zero.print = NULL, drop0trailing = FALSE, ...)
format.1.description: Format an R object for pretty printing.

format.info.description: Information is returned on how format(x, digits, nsmall)would be formatted.

require(package, lib.loc = NULL, quietly = FALSE,warn.conflicts = TRUE,character.only = FALSE)

format.pval.description: format.pval is intended for formatting p-values.

displayText: formatC(x, digits = NULL, width = NULL,format = NULL, flag = "", mode = NULL,big.mark = "", big.interval = 3L,small.mark = "", small.interval = 5L,decimal.mark = getOption("OutDec"),preserve.width = "individual", zero.print = NULL,drop0trailing = FALSE)

prettyNum(x, big.mark = "", big.interval = 3L,small.mark= "", small.interval = 5L,decimal.mark = getOption("OutDec"), input.d.mark = decimal.mark,preserve.width = c("common", "individual", "none"),zero.print = NULL, drop0trailing = FALSE, is.cmplx = NA,...)
formatC.description: Formatting numbers individually and flexibly, formatC() usingC style format specifications.

formatDL.displayText: formatDL(x, y, style = c("table", "list"), width = 0.9 * getOption("width"), indent = NULL)
formatDL.description: Format vectors of items and their descriptions as 2-columntables or LaTeX-style description lists.

gc.description: A call of gc causes a garbage collection to take place.gcinfo sets a flag so thatautomatic collection is either silent (verbose = FALSE) orprints memory usage statistics (verbose = TRUE).

gc.time.description: This function reports the time spent in garbage collection so far inthe R session while GC timing was enabled.

gctorture.description: Provokes garbage collection on (nearly) every memory allocation.Intended to ferret out memory protection bugs.  Also makes R runvery slowly, unfortunately.

getDLLRegisteredRoutines.description: This function allows us to query the set of routinesin a DLL that are registered with R to enhancedynamic lookup, error handling when calling native routines,and potentially security in the future.This function provides a description of each of theregistered routines in the DLL for the different interfaces,i.e. .C, .Call, .Fortranand .External.

stop.description: stop stops execution of the current expression and executesan error action.

getHook.description: These functions allow users to set actions to be taken before packagesare attached/detached and namespaces are (un)loaded.

getNativeSymbolInfo.description: This finds and returns a description of one or more dynamically loadedor ‘exported’ built-in native symbols.  For each name, itreturns information about the name of the symbol, the library in whichit is located and, if available, the number of arguments it expectsand by which interface it should be called (i.e .Call,.C, .Fortran, or.External). Additionally, it returns the address of thesymbol and this can be passed to other C routines.  Specifically, thisprovides a way to explicitly share symbols between differentdynamically loaded package libraries.  Also, it provides a way toquery where symbols were resolved, and aids diagnosing strangebehavior associated with dynamic resolution.

options.description: Allow the user to set and examine a variety of global optionswhich affect the way in which R computes and displays its results.

getTaskCallbackNames.description: This provides a way to get the names (or identifiers)for the currently registered task callbacksthat are invoked at the conclusion of each top-level task.These identifiers can be used to remove a callback.

sprintf.description: A wrapper for the C function sprintf, that returns a charactervector containing a formatted combination of text and variable values.

getwd.description: getwd returns an absolute filepath representing the currentworking directory of the R process; setwd(dir) is used to setthe working directory to dir.

gl.displayText: gl(n, k, length = n*k, labels = seq_len(n), ordered = FALSE)
gl.description: Generate factors by specifying the pattern of their levels.

displayText: grep(pattern, x, ignore.case = FALSE, perl = FALSE, value = FALSE, fixed = FALSE, useBytes = FALSE, invert = FALSE)
grepl(pattern, x, ignore.case = FALSE, perl = FALSE,fixed = FALSE, useBytes = FALSE)
sub(pattern, replacement, x, ignore.case = FALSE, perl = FALSE,fixed = FALSE, useBytes = FALSE)
gsub(pattern, replacement, x, ignore.case = FALSE, perl = FALSE, fixed = FALSE, useBytes = FALSE)
regexpr(pattern, text, ignore.case = FALSE, perl = FALSE,fixed = FALSE, useBytes = FALSE)
gregexpr(pattern, text, ignore.case = FALSE, perl = FALSE, fixed = FALSE, useBytes = FALSE)
regexec(pattern, text, ignore.case = FALSE,fixed = FALSE, useBytes = FALSE)
grep.description: grep, grepl, regexpr, gregexpr andregexec search for matches to argument pattern withineach element of a character vector: they differ in the format of andamount of detail in the results.

grepRaw.displayText: grepRaw(pattern, x, offset = 1L, ignore.case = FALSE,value = FALSE, fixed = FALSE, all = FALSE, invert = FALSE)
grepRaw.description: grepRaw searches for substring pattern matches within araw vector x.

grouping.description: grouping returns a permutation which rearranges its firstargument such that identical values are adjacent to each other.  Alsoreturned as attributes are the group-wise partitioning and the maximumgroup size.

gzcon.displayText: gzcon(con, level = 6, allowNonCompressed = TRUE, text = FALSE)
gzcon.description: gzcon provides a modified connection that wraps an existingconnection, and decompresses reads or compresses writes through thatconnection.  Standard gzip headers are assumed.

displayText: iconv(x, from = "", to = "", sub = NA, mark = TRUE, toRaw = FALSE)
iconv.description: This uses system facilities to convert a character vector betweenencodings: the ‘i’ stands for ‘internationalization’.

icuSetCollate.description: Controls the way collation is done by ICU (an optional part of the Rbuild).

identical.displayText: identical(x, y, num.eq = TRUE, single.NA = TRUE, attrib.as.set = TRUE,ignore.bytecode = TRUE, ignore.environment = FALSE)
identical.description: The safe and reliable way to test two objects for beingexactly equal.  It returns TRUE in this case,FALSE in every other case.

identity.description: A trivial identity function returning its argument.

ifelse.description: ifelse returns a value with the same shape astest which is filled with elements selectedfrom either yes or nodepending on whether the element of testis TRUE or FALSE.

interaction.displayText: interaction(..., drop = FALSE, sep = ".", lex.order = FALSE)
interaction.description: interaction computes a factor which represents the interactionof the given factors.  The result of interaction is always unordered.

interactive.description: Return TRUE when R is being used interactively andFALSE otherwise.

union.description: Performs set union, intersection, (asymmetric!) difference,equality and membership on two vectors.

rle.description: Compute the lengths and values of runs of equal values in a vector– or the reverse operation.

invisible.description: Return a (temporarily) invisible copy of an object.

is.atomic.description: is.atomic returns TRUE if x is of an atomic type(or NULL) and FALSE otherwise.

is.function.description: Checks whether its argument is a (primitive) function.

is.language.description: is.language returns TRUE if x is avariable name, a call, or anexpression.

is.object.description: A function rather for internal use.  It returns TRUE if theobject x has the R internal OBJECT bit set, andFALSE otherwise.  The OBJECT bit is set when a"class" attribute is added and removed when that attribute isremoved, so this is a very efficient way to check if an object has aclass attribute.  (S4 objects always should.)

is.single.description: is.single reports an error.  There are no single precisionvalues in R.

is.unsorted.description: Test if an object is not sorted (in increasing order), without thecost of sorting it.

displayText: ISOdatetime(year, month, day, hour, min, sec, tz = "")
ISOdate(year, month, day, hour = 12, min = 0, sec = 0, tz = "GMT")
ISOdatetime.description: Convenience wrappers to create date-times from numeric representations.

isSymmetric.description: Generic function to test if object is symmetric or not.Currently only a matrix method is implemented, where acomplex matrix Z must be “Hermitian” forisSymmetric(Z) to be true.

! x\nx & y\nx && y\nx | y\nx || y\nxor.text:
! x
x & y
x && y
x | y
x || y
xor
! x\nx & y\nx && y\nx | y\nx || y\nxor.snippet:
! x
x & y
x && y
x | y
x || y
xor
! x\nx & y\nx && y\nx | y\nx || y\nxor.prefix:
! x
x & y
x && y
x | y
x || y
xor
displayText: ! xx & yx && yx | yx || yxor(x, y)
! x\nx & y\nx && y\nx | y\nx || y\nxor.description: These operators act on raw, logical and number-like vectors.

jitter.description: Add a small amount of noise to a numeric vector.

weekdays.description: Extract the weekday, month or quarter, or the Julian time(days since some origin).  These are generic functions: the methodsfor the internal date-time classes are documented here.

displayText: kappa(z, exact = FALSE,norm = NULL, method = c("qr", "direct"), ...)
.kappa_tri(z, exact = FALSE, LINPACK = TRUE, norm = NULL, ...)
kappa.description: The condition number of a regular (square) matrix is the product ofthe norm of the matrix and the norm of its inverse (orpseudo-inverse), and hence depends on the kind of matrix-norm.

kronecker.description: Computes the generalised kronecker product of two arrays,X and Y.

displayText: svd(x, nu = min(n, p), nv = min(n, p), LINPACK = FALSE)
La.svd(x, nu = min(n, p), nv = min(n, p)
svd.description: Compute the singular-value decomposition of a rectangular matrix.

labels.description: Find a suitable set of labels from an object for use in printing orplotting, for example.  A generic function.

displayText: sapply(X, FUN, ..., simplify = TRUE, USE.NAMES = TRUE)
lapply.description: lapply returns a list of the same length as X, eachelement of which is the result of applying FUN to thecorresponding element of X.

La_version.description: Report the version of LAPACK in use.

Sys.getlocale.description: Get details of or set aspects of the locale for the R process.

length.description: Get or set the length of vectors (including lists) and factors, and ofany other R object for which a method has been defined.

lengths.description: Get the length of each element of a list or atomicvector (is.atomic) as an integer or numeric vector.

levels.description: levels provides access to the levels attribute of a variable.The first form returns the value of the levels of its argumentand the second sets the attribute.

libcurlVersion.description: Report version of libcurl in use.

library.dynam.description: Load the specified file of compiled code if it has not been loadedalready, or unloads it.

license.description: The license terms under which R is distributed.

list2env.displayText: list2env(x, envir = NULL, parent = parent.frame(), hash = (length(x) > 100), size = max(29L, length(x))
list2env.description: From a named list x, create anenvironment containing all list components as objects, or“multi-assign” from x into a pre-existing environment.

load.description: Reload datasets written with the function save.

Sys.localeconv.description: Get details of the numerical and monetary representations in thecurrent locale.

lower.tri.description: Returns a matrix of logicals the same size of a given matrix withentries TRUE in the lower or upper triangle.

displayText: ls(name, pos = -1L, envir = as.environment(pos), all.names = FALSE, pattern, sorted = TRUE)
objects(name, pos= -1L, envir = as.environment(pos),all.names = FALSE, pattern, sorted = TRUE)
ls.description: ls and objects return a vector of character stringsgiving the names of the objects in the specified environment.  Wheninvoked with no argument at the top level prompt, ls shows whatdata sets and functions a user has defined.  When invoked with noargument inside a function, ls returns the names of thefunction's local variables: this is useful in conjunction withbrowser.

make.names.description: Make syntactically valid names out of character vectors.

make.unique.description: Makes the elements of a character vector unique byappending sequence numbers to duplicates.

mapply.displayText: mapply(FUN, ..., MoreArgs = NULL, SIMPLIFY = TRUE, USE.NAMES = TRUE)
mapply.description: mapply is a multivariate version of sapply.mapply applies FUN to the first elements of each ...argument, the second elements, the third elements, and so on.Arguments are recycled if necessary.

margin.table.description: For a contingency table in array form, compute the sum of tableentries for a given index.

mat.or.vec.description: mat.or.vec creates an nr by nc zero matrix ifnc is greater than 1, and a zero vector of length nr ifnc equals 1.

displayText: match(x, table, nomatch = NA_integer_, incomparables = NULL)
match.description: match returns a vector of the positions of (first) matches ofits first argument in its second.

match.arg.description: match.arg matches arg against a table of candidatevalues as specified by choices, where NULL means to takethe first one.

match.call.displayText: match.call(definition = sys.function(sys.parent()), call = sys.call(sys.parent()), expand.dots = TRUE, envir = parent.frame(2L)
match.call.description: match.call returns a call in which all of the specified arguments arespecified by their full names.

match.fun.description: When called inside functions that take a function as argument, extractthe desired function object while avoiding undesired matching toobjects of other types.

max.description: Returns the (parallel) maxima and minima of the input values.

max.col.description: Find the maximum position for each row of a matrix, breaking ties at random.

mean.description: Generic function for the (trimmed) arithmetic mean.

memCompress.description: In-memory compression or decompression for raw vectors.

memory.profile.description: Lists the usage of the cons cells by SEXPREC type.

displayText: merge(x, y, by = intersect(names(x), names(y)),by.x = by, by.y = by, all = FALSE, all.x = all, all.y = all,sort = TRUE, suffixes = c(".x",".y"),incomparables = NULL, ...)
merge.description: Merge two data frames by common columns or row names, or do otherversions of database join operations.

message.description: Generate a diagnostic message from its arguments.

missing.description: missing can be used to test whether a value was specifiedas an argument to a function.

mode.description: Get or set the type or storage mode of an object.

names.description: Functions to get or set the names of an object.

nargs.description: When used inside a function body, nargs returns the number ofarguments supplied to that function, including positionalarguments left blank.

displayText: nchar(x, type = "chars", allowNA = FALSE, keepNA = FALSE)
nchar.description: nchar takes a character vector as an argument andreturns a vector whose elements contain the sizes ofthe corresponding elements of x.

nrow.description: nrow and ncol return the number of rows or columnspresent in x.NCOL and NROW do the same treating a vector as1-column matrix.

UseMethod.description: R possesses a simple generic function mechanism which can be used foran object-oriented style of programming.  Method dispatch takes placebased on the class(es) of the first argument to the generic function or ofthe object supplied as an argument to UseMethod or NextMethod.

nlevels.description: Return the number of levels which its argument has.

norm.description: Computes a matrix norm of x using LAPACK.  The norm can bethe one ("O") norm, the infinity ("I") norm, theFrobenius ("F") norm, the maximum modulus ("M") amongelements of a matrix, or the “spectral” or "2"-norm, asdetermined by the value of type.

normalizePath.description: Convert file paths to canonical form for the platform, to display themin a user-understandable form and so that relative and absolute paths canbe compared.

.NotYetImplemented.description: In order to pinpoint missing functionality, the R core team usesthese functions for missing R functions and not yet used arguments ofexisting R functions (which are typically there for compatibilitypurposes).

Sys.timezone.description: Information about time zones in R.  Sys.timezone returnsthe name of the current time zone.

on.exit.description: on.exit records the expression given as its argument as needingto be executed when the current function exits (either naturally or asthe result of an error).  This is useful for resetting graphicalparameters or performing other cleanup actions.

displayText: sort.list(x, partial = NULL, na.last = TRUE, decreasing = FALSE,method = c("shell", "quick", "radix")
order.description: order returns a permutation which rearranges its firstargument into ascending or descending order, breaking ties by furtherarguments. sort.list is the same, using only one argument.See the examples for how to use these functions to sort data frames,etc.

outer.description: The outer product of the arrays X and Y is the arrayA with dimension c(dim(X), dim(Y)) where elementA[c(arrayindex.x, arrayindex.y)]    = FUN(X[arrayindex.x], Y[arrayindex.y], ...).

258.description: Open parenthesis, (, and open brace, {, are.Primitive functions in R.

sys.call.description: These functions provide access to environments(‘frames’ in S terminology) associated with functions furtherup the calling stack.

parse.displayText: parse(file = "", n = NULL, text = NULL, prompt = "?",keep.source = getOption("keep.source"), srcfile,encoding = "unknown")
parse.description: parse returns the parsed but unevaluated expressions in alist.

paste.description: Concatenate vectors after converting to character.

path.expand.description: Expand a path name, for example by replacing a leading tilde by theuser's home directory (if defined on that platform).

pcre_config.description: Report some of the configuration options of the version of PCRE in usein this R session.

pmatch.displayText: pmatch(x, table, nomatch = NA_integer_, duplicates.ok = FALSE)
pmatch.description: pmatch seeks matches for the elements of its first argumentamong those of its second.

polyroot.description: Find zeros of a real or complex polynomial.

pos.to.env.description: Returns the environment at a specified position in the search path.

displayText: pretty(x, n = 5, min.n = n %/% 3,shrink.sml = 0.75, high.u.bias = 1.5, u5.bias = .5 + 1.5*high.u.bias, eps.correct = 0, ...)
pretty.description: Compute a  sequence of about n+1 equally spaced ‘round’values which cover the range of the values in x.The values are chosen so that they are 1, 2 or 5 times a power of 10.

.Primitive.description: .Primitive looks up by name a ‘primitive’(internally implemented) function.

displayText: print(x, quote = FALSE, max.levels = NULL,width = getOption("width"), ...)
print(x, digits = getOption("digits"), quote = FALSE,na.print = "", zero.print = "0", justify = "none", ...)
print.1.description: print prints its argument and returns it invisibly (viainvisible(x)).  It is a generic function which means thatnew printing methods can be easily added for new classes.

print.2.displayText: print(x, ..., digits = NULL,quote = FALSE, right = TRUE, row.names = TRUE)

print.3.displayText: print(x, digits = NULL, quote = TRUE,na.print = NULL, print.gap = NULL, right = FALSE,max = NULL, useSource = TRUE, ...)
print.3.description: print.default is the default method of the genericprint function which prints its argument.

proc.time.description: proc.time determines how much real and CPU time (in seconds)the currently running R process has already taken.

prmatrix.displayText: prmatrix(x, rowlab =, collab =, quote = TRUE, right = FALSE, na.print = NULL, ...)
prmatrix.description: An earlier method for printing matrices, provided for S compatibility.

prod.description: prod returns the product of all the valuespresent in its arguments.

prop.table.description: This is really sweep(x, margin, margin.table(x, margin), "/")for newbies, except that if margin has length zero, then onegets x/sum(x).

quit.description: The function quit or its alias q terminate the currentR session.

qr.X.description: Returns the original matrix from which the object was constructed orthe components of the decomposition.

R.home.description: Return the R home directory, or the full path to a component of theR installation.

R.Version.description: R.Version() provides detailed information about the version ofR running.

.Random.seed <- c.description: .Random.seed is an integer vector, containing the random numbergenerator (RNG) state for random number generation in R.  Itcan be saved and restored, but should not be altered by the user.

range.description: range returns a vector containing the minimum and maximum ofall the given arguments.

rank.description: Returns the sample ranks of the values in a vector.  Ties (i.e., equalvalues) and missing values can be handled in several ways.

rapply.displayText: rapply(object, f, classes = "ANY", deflt = NULL, how = c("unlist", "replace", "list"), ...)
rapply.description: rapply is a recursive version of lapply.

displayText: read.dcf(file, fields = NULL, all = FALSE, keep.white = NULL)
write.dcf(x, file = "", append = FALSE,indent = 0.1 * getOption("width"),width = 0.9 * getOption("width"),keep.white = NULL)
read.dcf.description: Reads or writes an R object from/to a file in Debian Control Fileformat.

displayText: readBin(con, what, n = 1L, size = NA_integer_, signed = TRUE,endian = .Platform$endian)
writeBin(object, con, size = NA_integer_, endian = .Platform$endian, useBytes = FALSE)
readBin.description: Read binary data from or write binary data to a connection or raw vector.

displayText: writeChar(object, con, nchars = nchar(object, type = "chars"),eos = "", useBytes = FALSE)
readChar.description: Transfer character strings to and from connections, without assumingthey are null-terminated on the connection.

readline.description: readline reads a line from the terminal (in interactive use).

readLines.displayText: readLines(con = stdin(), n = -1L, ok = TRUE, warn = TRUE,encoding = "unknown", skipNul = FALSE)
readLines.description: Read some or all text lines from a connection.

displayText: saveRDS(object, file = "", ascii = FALSE, version = NULL,compress = TRUE, refhook = NULL)
saveRDS.description: Functions to write a single R object to a file, and to restore it.

readRenviron.description: Read as file such as ‘.Renviron’ or ‘Renviron.site’ in theformat described in the help for Startup, and set environmentvariables as defined in the file.

Recall.description: Recall is used as a placeholder for the name of the functionin which it is called.  It allows the definition of recursivefunctions which still work after being renamed, see example below.

regmatches.description: Extract or replace matched substrings from match data obtained byregexpr, gregexpr orregexec.

displayText: remove(..., list = character(), pos = -1, envir = as.environment(pos), inherits = FALSE)
rm(..., list = character(), pos = -1, envir = as.environment(pos), inherits = FALSE)
remove.description: remove and rm can be used to remove objects.  These canbe specified successively as character strings, or in the charactervector list, or through a combination of both.  All objectsthus specified will be removed.

rep.description: rep replicates the values in x.  It is a genericfunction, and the (internal) default method is described here.

replace.description: replace replaces the values in xwith indices given in list by those given in values.If necessary, the values in values are recycled.

tracemem.description: This function marks an object so that a message is printed whenever theinternal code copies the object.  It is amajor cause of hard-to-predict memory use in R.

displayText: trace(what, tracer, exit, at, print, signature,where = topenv(parent.frame()), edit = FALSE)
trace.description: A call to trace allows you to insert debugging code (e.g., acall to browser or recover) at chosenplaces in any function.  A call to untrace cancels the tracing.Specified methods can be traced the same way, without tracing allcalls to the function.  Trace code can be any R expression.  Tracingcan be temporarily turned on or off globally by calling tracingState.

rev.description: rev provides a reversed version of its argument.  It is genericfunction with a default method for vectors and one fordendrograms.

row.description: Returns a matrix of integers indicating their row number in amatrix-like object, or a factor indicating the row labels.

row.names.description: All data frames have a row names attribute, a character vector oflength the number of rows with no duplicates nor missing values.

displayText: rowsum(x, group, reorder = TRUE, na.rm = FALSE, ...)
rowsum(x, group, reorder = TRUE, na.rm = FALSE, ...)
rowsum.description: Compute column sums across rows of a numeric matrix-like object foreach level of a grouping variable.  rowsum is generic, with amethod for data frames and a default method for vectors and matrices.

.libPaths.description: .libPaths gets/sets the library trees within which packages arelooked for.

displayText: sample(x, size, replace = FALSE, prob = NULL)
sample.int(n, size = n, replace = FALSE, prob = NULL)
sample.description: sample takes a sample of the specified size from the elementsof x using either with or without replacement.

displayText: save(..., list = character(), file = stop("'file' must be specified"), ascii = FALSE, version = NULL, envir = parent.frame(), compress = isTRUE(!ascii), compression_level, eval.promises = TRUE, precheck = TRUE)
save.image(file = ".RData", version = NULL, ascii = FALSE, compress = !ascii, safe = TRUE)
save.description: save writes an external representation of R objects to thespecified file.  The objects can be read back from the file at a laterdate by using the function load or attach(or data in some cases).

scale.description: scale is generic function whose default method centers and/orscales the columns of a numeric matrix.

scan.displayText: scan(file = "", what = double(), nmax = -1, n = -1, sep = "", quote = if(identical(sep, "\n")) "" else "'\"", dec = ".", skip = 0, nlines = 0, na.strings = "NA", flush = FALSE, fill = FALSE, strip.white = FALSE, quiet = FALSE, blank.lines.skip = TRUE, multi.line = TRUE, comment.char = "", allowEscapes = FALSE, fileEncoding = "", encoding = "unknown", text, skipNul = FALSE)
scan.description: Read data into a vector or list from the console or file.

search.description: Gives a list of attached packages(see library), and R objects, usuallydata.frames.

displayText: seq(from = 1, to = 1, by = ((to - from)/(length.out - 1)),length.out = NULL, along.with = NULL, ...)
seq.description: Generate regular sequences.  seq is a standard generic with adefault method.  seq.int is a primitive which can bemuch faster but has a few restrictions.  seq_along andseq_len are very fast primitives for two common cases.

seq.1.displayText: seq(from, to, by, length.out = NULL, along.with = NULL, ...)
seq.1.description: The method for seq for objects of class class"Date" representing calendar dates.

seq.2.displayText: seq(from, to, by, length.out = NULL, along.with = NULL, ...)
seq.2.description: The method for seq for date-time classes.

sequence.description: For each element of nvec the sequence seq_len(nvec[i])is created.  These are concatenated and the result returned.

displayText: serialize(object, connection, ascii, xdr = TRUE,version = NULL, refhook = NULL)
serialize.description: A simple low-level interface for serializing to connections.

displayText: setTimeLimit(cpu = Inf, elapsed = Inf, transient = FALSE)
setTimeLimit.description: Functions to set CPU and/or elapsed time limits for top-levelcomputations or the current session.

system.displayText: system(command, intern = FALSE, ignore.stdout = FALSE, ignore.stderr = FALSE, wait = TRUE, input = NULL, show.output.on.console = TRUE, minimized = FALSE, invisible = TRUE)
system.description: system invokes the OS command specified by command.

shQuote.description: Quote a string to be passed to an operating system shell.

sign.description: sign returns a vector with the signs of the correspondingelements of x (the sign of a real number is 1, 0, or -1if the number is positive, zero, or negative, respectively).

displayText: sink(file = NULL, append = FALSE, type = c("output", "message"), split = FALSE)
sink.description: sink diverts R output to a connection (and stops such diversions).

slice.index.description: Returns a matrix of integers indicating the number of their slice in agiven array.

socketSelect.description: Waits for the first of several socket connections to become available.

solve.description: This generic function solves the equation a %*% x = b for x,where b can be either a vector or a matrix.

displayText: sort.int(x, partial = NULL, na.last = NA, decreasing = FALSE, method = c("shell", "quick"), index.return = FALSE)
sort.description: Sort (or order) a vector or factor (partially) intoascending or descending order.  For ordering along more than onevariable, e.g., for sorting data frames, see order.

source.displayText: source(file, local = FALSE, echo = verbose, print.eval = echo, verbose = getOption("verbose"), prompt.echo = getOption("prompt"), max.deparse.length = 150, chdir = FALSE, encoding = getOption("encoding"), continue.echo = getOption("continue"), skip.echo = 0, keep.source = getOption("keep.source")
source.description: source causes R to accept its input from the named file or URLor connection.  Input is read and parsed from that fileuntil the end of the file is reached, then the parsed expressions areevaluated sequentially in the chosen environment.

displayText: split(x, f, drop = FALSE, ...) <- valueunsplit(value, f, drop = FALSE)
split.description: split divides the data in the vector x into the groupsdefined by f.  The replacement forms replace valuescorresponding to such a division.  unsplit reverses the effect ofsplit.

stopifnot.description: If any of the expressions in ... are not allTRUE, stop is called, producing an error messageindicating the first of the elements of ... which werenot true.

strrep.description: Repeat the character strings in a character vector a given number oftimes (i.e., concatenate the respective numbers of copies of thestrings).

strsplit.displayText: strsplit(x, split, fixed = FALSE, perl = FALSE, useBytes = FALSE)
strsplit.description: Split the elements of a character vector x into substringsaccording to the matches to substring split within them.

strtoi.description: Convert strings to integers according to the given base using the Cfunction strtol, or choose a suitable base following the C rules.

strtrim.description: Trim character strings to specified display widths.

structure.description: structure returns the given object with furtherattributes set.

strwrap.displayText: strwrap(x, width = 0.9 * getOption("width"), indent = 0,exdent = 0, prefix = "", simplify = TRUE, initial = prefix)
strwrap.description: Each character string in the input is first split into paragraphs (orlines containing whitespace only).  The paragraphs are then formattedby breaking lines at word boundaries.  The target columns for wrappinglines and the indentation of the first and all subsequent lines of aparagraph can be controlled independently.

subset.description: Return subsets of vectors, matrices or data frames which meet conditions.

displayText: substr(x, start, stop) <- valuesubstring(text, first, last = 1000000L) <- value)
substr.description: Extract or replace substrings in a character vector.

sum.description: sum returns the sum of all the valuespresent in its arguments.

displayText: warning(..., call. = TRUE, immediate. = FALSE, noBreaks. = FALSE,domain = NULL)
warning.description: Generates a warning message that corresponds to its argument(s) and(optionally) the expression or function from which it was called.

sweep.displayText: sweep(x, MARGIN, STATS, FUN = "-", check.margin = TRUE, ...)
sweep.description: Return an array obtained from an input array by sweeping out a summarystatistic.

switch.description: switch evaluates EXPR and accordingly chooses one of thefurther arguments (in ...).

Sys.time.description: Sys.time and Sys.Date returns the system's idea of thecurrent date with and without time.

Sys.getenv.description: Sys.getenv obtains the values of the environment variables.

Sys.getpid.description: Get the process ID of the R Session.  It is guaranteed by theoperating system that two R sessions running simultaneously willhave different IDs, but it is possible that R sessions running atdifferent times will have the same ID.

Sys.glob.description: Function to do wildcard expansion (also known as ‘globbing’) onfile paths.

Sys.readlink.description: Find out if a file path is a symbolic link, and if so what it islinked to, via the system call readlink.

Sys.setenv.description: Sys.setenv sets environment variables (for other processescalled from within R or future calls to Sys.getenv fromthis R process).

Sys.setFileTime.description: Uses system calls to set the times on a file or directory.

Sys.sleep.description: Suspend execution of R expressions for a specified time interval.

sys.source.displayText: sys.source(file, envir = baseenv(), chdir = FALSE, keep.source = getOption("keep.source.pkgs")
sys.source.description: Parses expressions in the given file, and then successively evaluatesthem in the specified environment.

Sys.which.description: This is an interface to the system command which, or to anemulation on Windows.

system.file.description: Finds the full file names of files in packages etc.

system.time.description: Return CPU (and other) times that expr used.

system2.displayText: system2(command, args = character(),stdout = "", stderr = "", stdin = "", input = NULL,env = character(), wait = TRUE,minimized = FALSE, invisible = TRUE)
system2.description: system2 invokes the OS command specified by command.

t.description: Given a matrix or data.frame x,t returns the transpose of x.

tabulate.displayText: tabulate(bin, nbins = max(1, bin, na.rm = TRUE)

filter.displayText: filter(x, filter, method = c("convolution", "recursive"), sides = 2, circular = FALSE, init)

kmeans.description: Perform k-means clustering on a data matrix.

fitted.description: fitted is a generic function which extracts fitted values fromobjects returned by modeling functions.  fitted.values is analias for it.

getInitial.description: This function evaluates initial parameter estimates for a nonlinearregression model.  If data is a parameterized data frame orpframe object, its parameters attribute is returned.Otherwise the object is examined to see if it contains a call to aselfStart object whose initial attribute can beevaluated.

Optionally a function isapplied to the index of data points contained in the cluster.

influence.description: This function provides the basic quantities which areused in forming a wide variety of diagnostics forchecking the quality of regression fits.

nlm.description: This function carries out a minimization of the function fusing a Newton-type algorithm.  See the references for details.

poisson.test.description: Performs an exact test of a simple null hypothesis about therate parameter in Poisson distribution, or for theratio between two rate parameters.

power.description: Creates a link object based on the link functionη = μ ^ λ.

predict.description: predict is a generic function for predictions from the results ofvarious model fitting functions.  The function invokes particularmethods which depend on the class ofthe first argument.
Forecast from models fitted by arima.

predict.1.description: Obtains predictions and optionally estimates standard errors of thosepredictions from a fitted generalized linear model object.

predict.2.description: Computes predictions and prediction intervals for models fitted bythe Holt-Winters method.

predict.3.displayText: predict(object, newdata, se.fit = FALSE, scale = NULL, df = Inf,interval = c("none", "confidence", "prediction"),level = 0.95, type = c("response", "terms"),terms = NULL, na.action = na.pass,pred.var = res.var/weights, weights = 1, ...)
predict.3.description: Predicted values based on linear model object.

predict.4.displayText: predict(object, newdata = NULL, se = FALSE,na.action = na.pass, ...)
predict.4.description: Predictions from a loess fit, optionally with standard errors.

predict.5.displayText: predict(object, newdata , se.fit = FALSE, scale = NULL, df = Inf,interval = c("none", "confidence", "prediction"),level = 0.95, ...)
predict.5.description: predict.nls produces predicted values, obtained by evaluatingthe regression function in the frame newdata.  If the logicalse.fit is TRUE, standard errors of the predictions arecalculated.  If the numeric argument scale is set (withoptional df), it is used as the residual standard deviation inthe computation of the standard errors, otherwise this is extractedfrom the model fit.  Setting intervals specifies computation ofconfidence or prediction (tolerance) intervals at the specifiedlevel.

predict.6.description: Predict a smoothing spline fit at new points, return the derivative ifdesired. The predicted fit is linear beyond the original data.

StructTS.description: Fit a structural model for a time series by maximum likelihood.

preplot.description: Compute an object to be used for plots relating to the given model object.

print.4.description: Printing objects of class "htest" or "power.htest",respectively, by simple print methods.

print(x, digits = max(3, getOption("digits") - 3),symbolic.cor = x$symbolic.cor,signif.stars = getOption("show.signif.stars"), ...)

print.5.description: Notably for calendar related time series objects,  format and print methods showing years,months and or quarters respectively.

xtabs.description: Create a contingency table (optionally a sparse matrix) fromcross-classifying factors, usually contained in a data frame,using a formula interface.

printCoefmat.description: Utility function to be used in higher-level printmethods, such as those for summary.lm,summary.glm and anova.  Thegoal is to provide a flexible interface with smart defaults suchthat often, only x needs to be specified.

profile.description: Investigates behavior of objective function near the solutionrepresented by fitted.

profile.1.description: Investigates the profile log-likelihood function for a fitted model ofclass "nls".

proj.description: proj returns a matrix or list of matrices giving the projectionsof the data onto the terms of a linear model.  It is most frequentlyused for aov models.

varimax.description: These functions ‘rotate’ loading matrices in factor analysis.

prop.test.displayText: prop.test(x, n, p = NULL,alternative = c("two.sided", "less", "greater"),conf.level = 0.95, correct = TRUE)
prop.test.description: prop.test can be used for testing the null that theproportions (probabilities of success) in several groups are thesame, or that they equal certain given values.

prop.trend.test.description: Performs chi-squared test for trend in proportions, i.e., a testasymptotically optimal for local alternatives where the log odds varyin proportion with score.  By default, score is chosenas the group numbers.

displayText: ptukey(q, nmeans, df, nranges = 1, lower.tail = TRUE, log.p = FALSE)
qtukey(p, nmeans, df, nranges = 1, lower.tail = TRUE, log.p = FALSE)
ptukey.description: Functions of the distribution of the studentized range, R/s,where R is the range of a standard normal sample anddf*s^2 is independently distributed aschi-squared with df degrees of freedom, see pchisq.

qqline(y, datax = FALSE, distribution = qnorm, probs = c(0.25, 0.75), qtype = 7, ...)
qqplot(x, y, plot.it = TRUE, xlab = deparse(substitute(x)), ylab = deparse(substitute(y)), ...)
qqnorm.description: qqnorm is a generic function the default method of whichproduces a normal QQ plot of the values in y.qqline adds a line to a “theoretical”, by defaultnormal, quantile-quantile plot which passes through the probsquantiles, by default the first and third quartiles.

quade.test.description: Performs a Quade test with unreplicated blocked data.

displayText: quantile(x, probs = seq(0, 1, 0.25), na.rm = FALSE, names = TRUE, type = 7, ...)
quantile.description: The generic function quantile produces sample quantilescorresponding to the given probabilities.The smallest observation corresponds to a probability of 0 and thelargest to a probability of 1.

r2dtable.description: Generate random 2-way tables with given marginals using Patefield'salgorithm.

rect.hclust.displayText: rect.hclust(tree, k = NULL, which = NULL, x = NULL, h = NULL,border = 2, cluster = NULL)
rect.hclust.description: Draws rectangles around the branches of a dendrogram highlighting thecorresponding clusters. First the dendrogram is cut at a certainlevel, then a rectangle is drawn around selected branches.

relevel.description: The levels of a factor are re-ordered so that the level specified byref is first and the others are moved down. This is usefulfor contr.treatment contrasts which take the first level asthe reference.

reorder.description: reorder is a generic function.  The "default" methodtreats its first argument as a categorical variable, and reorders itslevels based on the values of a second variable, usually numeric.

reorder.1.description: A method for the generic function reorder.

replications.description: Returns a vector or a list of the number of replicates foreach term in the formula.

displayText: reshape(data, varying = NULL, v.names = NULL, timevar = "time",idvar = "id", ids = 1:NROW(data),times = seq_along(varying[[1]]),drop = NULL, direction, new.row.names = NULL,sep = ".",split = if (sep == "") {list(regexp = "[A-Za-z][0-9]", include = TRUE)
} else {list(regexp = sep, include = FALSE, fixed = TRUE)})
reshape.description: This function reshapes a data frame between ‘wide’ format withrepeated measurements in separate columns of the same record and‘long’ format with the repeated measurements in separaterecords.

residuals.description: residuals is a generic function which extracts model residualsfrom objects returned by modeling functions.

runmed.displayText: runmed(x, k, endrule = c("median", "keep", "constant"), algorithm = NULL, print.level = 0)
runmed.description: Compute running medians of odd span.  This is the ‘most robust’scatter plot smoothing possible.  For efficiency (and historicalreason), you can use one of two different algorithms giving identicalresults.

rWishart.description: Generate n random matrices, distributed according to theWishart distribution with parameters Sigma and df,W_p(Sigma, df).

sd.description: This function computes the standard deviation of the values inx.If na.rm is TRUE then missing values are removed beforecomputation proceeds.

displayText: se.contrast(object, contrast.obj, coef = contr.helmert(ncol(contrast))[, 1], data = NULL, ...)
se.contrast.description: Returns the standard errors for one or more contrasts in an aovobject.

setNames.description: This is a convenience function that sets the names on an object andreturns the object.  It is most useful at the end of a functiondefinition where one is creating the object to be returned and wouldprefer not to store it under a name just so the names can be assigned.

shapiro.test.description: Performs the Shapiro-Wilk test of normality.

sigma.description: Extract the estimated standard deviation of the errors, the“residual standard deviation” (misnomed also“residual standard error”, e.g., insummary.lm()'s output, from a fitted model).

simulate.description: Simulate one or more responses from the distributioncorresponding to a fitted model object.

smooth.spline.description: Fits a cubic smoothing spline to the supplied data.

smoothEnds.description: Smooth end points of a vector y using subsequently smallermedians and Tukey's end point rule at the very end. (of odd span),

spectrum.description: The spectrum function estimates the spectral density of atime series.

spec.ar.displayText: spec.ar(x, n.freq, order = NULL, plot = TRUE, na.action = na.fail,method = "yule-walker", ...)

spec.pgram.description: spec.pgram calculates the periodogram using a fast Fouriertransform, and optionally smooths the result with a series ofmodified Daniell smoothers (moving averages giving half weight tothe end values).

spec.taper.description: Apply a cosine-bell taper to a time series.

displayText: spline(x, y = NULL, n = 3*length(x), method = "fmm", xmin = min(x), xmax = max(x), xout, ties = mean)
splinefun.description: Perform cubic (or Hermite) spline interpolation of given data points,returning either a list of points obtained by the interpolation or afunction performing the interpolation.

SSasymp.description: This selfStart model evaluates the asymptotic regressionfunction and its gradient.  It has an initial attribute thatwill evaluate initial estimates of the parameters Asym, R0,and lrc for a given set of data.

SSasympOff.description: This selfStart model evaluates an alternative parametrizationof the asymptoticregression function and the gradient with respect to those parameters.It has an initialattribute that creates initial estimates of the parametersAsym, lrc, and c0.

SSasympOrig.description: This selfStart model evaluates the asymptotic regressionfunction through the origin and its gradient.  It has aninitial attribute that will evaluate initial estimates of theparameters Asym and lrc for a given set of data.

SSbiexp.description: This selfStart model evaluates the biexponential model functionand its gradient.  It has an initial attribute thatcreates initial estimates of the parameters A1, lrc1,A2, and lrc2.

SSfol.description: This selfStart model evaluates the first-order compartmentfunction and its gradient.  It has an initial attribute thatcreates initial estimates of the parameters lKe, lKa,and lCl.

SSfpl.description: This selfStart model evaluates the four-parameter logisticfunction and its gradient.  It has an initial attribute thatwill evaluate initial estimates of the parameters A, B,xmid, and scal for a given set of data.

SSgompertz.description: This selfStart model evaluates the Gompertz growth modeland its gradient.  It has an initial attribute thatcreates initial estimates of the parameters Asym,b2, and b3.

SSlogis.description: This selfStart model evaluates the logisticfunction and its gradient.  It has an initial attribute thatcreates initial estimates of the parameters Asym,xmid, and scal.

SSmicmen.description: This selfStart model evaluates the Michaelis-Menten model andits gradient.  It has an initial attribute thatwill evaluate initial estimates of the parameters Vm and K

SSweibull.description: This selfStart model evaluates the Weibull model for growthcurve data and its gradient.  It has an initial attribute thatwill evaluate initial estimates of the parameters Asym, Drop,lrc, and pwr for a given set of data.

stat.anova.displayText: stat.anova(table, test = c("Rao","LRT", "Chisq", "F", "Cp"), scale, df.scale, n)

step.description: Select a formula-based model by AIC.

stl.description: Decompose a time series into seasonal, trend and irregular componentsusing loess, acronym STL.

else c(".", "|"), legend = length(symbols) >= 3, na = "?", eps = 1e-5, numeric.x = is.numeric(x), corr = missing(cutpoints) && numeric.x, show.max = if(corr) "1", show.min = NULL, abbr.colnames = has.colnames, lower.triangular = corr && is.numeric(x) && is.matrix(x), diag.lower.tri = corr && !is.null(show.max)

termplot.displayText: termplot(model, data = NULL, envir = environment(formula(model)), partial.resid = FALSE, rug = FALSE, terms = NULL, se = FALSE, xlabs = NULL, ylabs = NULL, main = NULL, col.term = 2, lwd.term = 1.5, col.se = "orange", lty.se = 2, lwd.se = 1, col.res = "gray", cex = 1, pch = par("pch"), col.smth = "darkred", lty.smth = 2, span.smth = 2/3, ask = dev.interactive() && nb.fig < n.tms, use.factor.levels = TRUE, smooth = NULL, ylim = "common", plot = TRUE, transform.x = FALSE, ...)

toeplitz.description: Forms a symmetric Toeplitz matrix given its first row.

uniroot.description: The function uniroot searches the interval from lowerto upper for a root (i.e., zero) of the function f withrespect to its first argument.

update.1.description: update.formula is used to update model formulae.This typically involves adding or dropping terms,but updates can be more general.

displayText: var.test(x, y, ratio = 1, alternative = c("two.sided", "less", "greater"), conf.level = 0.95, ...)
var.test.description: Performs an F test to compare the variances of two samples from normalpopulations.

vcov.description: Returns the variance-covariance matrix of the main parameters ofa fitted model object.

weighted.residuals.description: Computed weighted residuals from a linear model fit.

weights.description: weights is a generic function which extracts fitting weights fromobjects returned by modeling functions.

window(x, ...) <- valuewindow(x, start, end, frequency, deltat, ...) <- value)
window.description: window is a generic function whichextracts the subset of the object xobserved between the times start and end. If afrequency is specified, the series is then re-sampled at the newfrequency.

.checkMFClasses.description: .checkMFClasses checks if the variables used in a predictmethod agree in type with those used for fitting.

add_datalist.description: The data() command with no arguments lists all thedatasets available via data in attached packages, and to do so aper-package list is installed.  Creating that list at install time canbe slow for packages with huge datasets, and can be expedited by asupplying ‘data/datalist’ file.

displayText: parse_Rd(file, srcfile = NULL, encoding = "unknown", verbose = FALSE, fragment = FALSE, warningCalls = TRUE,	 macros = file.path(R.home("share"), "Rd", "macros", "system.Rd"), permissive = FALSE)
parse_Rd.description: This function reads an R documentation (Rd) file and parses it, forprocessing by other functions.

assertError.description: When testing code, it is not sufficient to check that results are correct,but also that errors or warnings are signalled in appropriatesituations.  The functions described here provide a convenientfacility for doing so.  The three functions check that evaluating thesupplied expression produces an error, a warning or one of aspecified list of conditions, respectively.  If the assertion fails,an error is signalled.

bibstyle.description: This function defines and registers styles for renderingbibentry objects into ‘Rd’ format, for laterconversion to text, HTML, etc.

pkgVignettes(package, dir, subdirs = NULL, lib.loc = NULL,	 output = FALSE, source = FALSE, check = FALSE)

checkDocFiles.description: Functions for performing various quality checks.

checkFF.displayText: checkFF(package, dir, file, lib.loc = NULL,registration = FALSE, check_DUP = FALSE,verbose = getOption("verbose")
checkFF.description: Performs checks on calls to compiled code from R code.  Currently onlychecks whether the interface functions such as .C and.Fortran are called with a "NativeSymbolInfo"first argument or with argument PACKAGE specified, which ishighly recommended to avoid name clashes in foreign function calls.

checkMD5sums.description: checkMD5sums checks the files against a file ‘MD5’.

checkPoFile.description: These functions compare formats embedded in English messageswith translated strings to check for consistency.  checkPoFilechecks one file, while checkPoFiles checks all files for a specifiedlanguage.

checkRd.displayText: checkRd(Rd, defines = .Platform$OS.type, stages = "render",unknownOK = TRUE, listOK = TRUE, ..., def_enc = FALSE)
checkRd.description: Check an help file or the output of the parse_Rd function.

checkRdaFiles.description: This reports for each of the files produced by save the size,if it was saved in ASCII or XDR binary format, and if it wascompressed (and if so in what format).

checkTnF.description: Checks the specified R package or code file for occurrences ofT or F, and gathers the expression containing these.This is useful as in R T and F are just variables whichare set to the logicals TRUE and FALSE by default, butare not reserved words and hence can be overwritten by the user.Hence, one should always use TRUE and FALSE for thelogicals.

checkVignettes.displayText: checkVignettes(package, dir, lib.loc = NULL, tangle = TRUE, weave = TRUE, latex = FALSE, workdir = c("tmp", "src", "cur"), keepfiles = FALSE)

displayText: compactPDF(paths, qpdf = Sys.which(Sys.getenv("R_QPDF", "qpdf")), gs_cmd = Sys.getenv("R_GSCMD", ""), gs_quality = Sys.getenv("GS_QUALITY", "none"), gs_extras = character())

displayText: read.table(file, header = FALSE, sep = "", quote = "\"'", dec = ".", numerals = c("allow.loss", "warn.loss", "no.loss"), row.names, col.names, as.is = !stringsAsFactors, na.strings = "NA", colClasses = NA, nrows = -1, skip = 0, check.names = TRUE, fill = !blank.lines.skip, strip.white = FALSE, blank.lines.skip = TRUE, comment.char = "#", allowEscapes = FALSE, flush = FALSE, stringsAsFactors = default.stringsAsFactors(), fileEncoding = "", encoding = "unknown", text, skipNul = FALSE)
read.csv(file, header = TRUE, sep = ",", quote = "\"", dec = ".", fill = TRUE, comment.char = "", ...)
read.csv2(file, header = TRUE, sep = ";", quote = "\"",dec = ",", fill = TRUE, comment.char = "", ...)

read.delim2(file, header = TRUE, sep = "\t", quote = "\"",dec = ",", fill = TRUE, comment.char = "", ...)
read.table.description: Reads a file in table format and creates a data frame from it, withcases corresponding to lines and variables to fields in the file.

remove.packages.description: Removes installed packages/bundles and updates index informationas necessary.

removeSource.description: When options("keep.source") is TRUE, a copy of theoriginal source code to a function is stored with it.  This functionremoves that copy.

Rprof.displayText: Rprof(filename = "Rprof.out", append = FALSE, interval = 0.02, memory.profiling = FALSE, gc.profiling = FALSE,line.profiling = FALSE, numfiles = 100L, bufsize = 10000L)
Rprof.description: Enable or disable profiling of the execution of R expressions.

Rprofmem.description: Enable or disable reporting of memory allocation in R.

RShowDoc.description: Utility function to find and display R documentation.

RSiteSearch.description: Search for key words or phrases inhelp pages, vignettes or task views, using the search engineat http://search.r-project.org and view them in a web browser.

rtags.displayText: rtags(path = ".", pattern = "\\.[RrSs]$",recursive = FALSE,src = list.files(path = path, pattern = pattern, full.names = TRUE, recursive = recursive),keep.re = NULL,ofile = "", append = FALSE,verbose = getOption("verbose")
rtags.description: rtags provides etags-like indexing capabilities for R code,using R's own parser.

displayText: RtangleSetup(file, syntax, output = NULL, annotate = TRUE, split = FALSE, quiet = FALSE, ...)
Rtangle.description: A driver for Stangle that extracts R code chunks.

displayText: RweaveLatexSetup(file, syntax, output = NULL, quiet = FALSE, debug = FALSE, stylepath, ...)
RweaveLatex.description: A driver for Sweave that translates R code chunks inLaTeX files.

select.list.displayText: select.list(choices, preselect = NULL, multiple = FALSE,title = NULL, graphics = getOption("menu.graphics")
select.list.description: Select item(s) from a character vector.

setRepositories.description: Interact with the user to choose the package repositories to be used.

stack.description: Stacking vectors concatenates multiple vectors into a single vectoralong with a factor indicating where each observation originated.Unstacking reverses this operation.

displayText: Sweave(file, driver = RweaveLatex(), syntax = getOption("SweaveSyntax"), encoding = "", ...)
Sweave.description: Sweave provides a flexible framework for mixing text and R/S codefor automatic report generation.  The basic idea is to replace thecode with its output, such that the final document only contains thetext and the output of the statistical analysis: however, the sourcecode can also be included.

displayText: str(object, max.level = NA,vec.len= strO$vec.len, digits.d = strO$digits.d,nchar.max = 128, give.attr = TRUE,give.head = TRUE, give.length = give.head,width = getOption("width"), nest.lev = 0,indent.str = paste(rep.int(" ", max(0, nest.lev + 1)), collapse = ".."),comp.str = "$ ", no.list = FALSE, envir = baseenv(),strict.width = strO$strict.width,formatNum = strO$formatNum, list.len = 99, ...)
str.description: Compactly display the internal structure of an R object, adiagnostic function and an alternative to summary(and to some extent, dput).  Ideally, only one line foreach ‘basic’ structure is displayed.  It is especially well suitedto compactly display the (abbreviated) contents of (possibly nested)lists.  The idea is to give reasonable output for any Robject.  It calls args for (non-primitive) function objects.

summaryRprof.displayText: summaryRprof(filename = "Rprof.out", chunksize = 5000,memory = c("none", "both", "tseries", "stats"),lines = c("hide", "show", "both"),index = 2, diff = TRUE, exclude = NULL,basenames = 1)
summaryRprof.description: Summarise the output of the Rprof function to show theamount of time used by different R functions.

SweaveSyntConv.description: This function converts the syntax of files in Sweaveformat to another Sweave syntax definition.

tar.displayText: tar(tarfile, files = NULL,compression = c("none", "gzip", "bzip2", "xz"),compression_level = 6, tar = Sys.getenv("tar"),extra_flags = "")

type.convert.description: Convert a character vector to logical, integer, numeric, complex orfactor as appropriate.
